ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Appert's Foodservice's goal as an independent, family owned, broadline foodservice distributor is to provide quality, friendly service with the delivery of every complete and accurate order. We provide you with the national and local brands you know and trust, and we also produce our own unique items at our USDA-inspected processing facility with competitive price points.



Appert's delivers more than just groceries - we are committed to providing you with the tools and services necessary to help you succeed. As your distributor of choice we partner with you for your success.



The Appert's Foodservice management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  Appert's Foodservice's safety and environmental policies are administered by the General Manager, who conducts periodic inspections of the facility to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs, including the OSHA Process Safety Management and EPA Risk Management Program.





STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The ammonia refrigeration system at 900 S. Highway 10 in St. Cloud, Minnesota was constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations including the International Fire and Mechanical Codes at the time of construction.  



The ammonia refrigeration system is a closed system that cycles the refrigerant from liquid to gas and back again.  The system, consisting of vessels, piping, valves, and process equipment, cycles 13,470 pounds of ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for dock, blast freezer, and cooler/freezer storage. The majority of System #1 is located in the

Distribution Engine Room including vessels and compressors, except for the -20F Recirculator (V-6) and its associated pumps and oil pot (V6-OP) which are located outside the Distribution Engine Room.  The condensers are mounted on the Distribution Engine Room roof, and the evaporators are located in their respective cold storage areas.  





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the following risk management regulations:



1)  OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM); and

2)  EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP).



These regulations impose numerous requirements on the facility to ensure the safety of the public and on site workers.  The following summarizes the key compliance programs that have been implemented by Appert's Foodservice to prevent the accidental release of ammonia at the facility.  The Operating Procedures program ensures that the ammonia system is operated in a safe manner.  The Training program ensures that personnel fully understand how to perform their jobs in a safe manner.  The Mechanical Integrity program ensures that the ammonia system is in proper working condition based upon routine testing, inspections, and maintenance according to manufacturer's specifications and industry standards.  The Management of Change program ensures that process modifications are implemented in a safe manner.  The Pre Startup Safety Review program ensures that adequate safety measures are in place before ammonia is introduced into a process.  The Hot Work Permit program ensures that the Appert's Foodservice employees and contractors perform hot work (e.g. welding) in a safe manner.  The Contractor Safety program ensures that contractors understand the hazards of ammonia and must take specified precautions to safely complete job requirements.



It is important to note that the refrigeration system, System #1, has been designed with several s

afety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  The facility has also installed ammonia sensors for System #1 which are located in the Distribution Engine Room which activates the audible/visual alarm and turns the exhaust fan on at low level and in the refrigeration spaces which activates the audible/visual alarm at low level.  The ammonia sensors will alert operators of an ammonia leak.  The refrigeration contractor is notified in the event that an ammonia sensor is triggered.  





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following:



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



- On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

- Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



Based on the above definition, at the time the Process Hazard Analysis was conducted revealed that there have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in the last five years (December 2006 - December 2011). In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.





EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN



The Appert's Foodservice facility has an emergency response plan in effect.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) has been developed by Appert's Foodservice and is included in the Emergency Planning and Response s

ection of the PSM/RMP document which is maintained at the facility.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



1. To save lives.

2. To minimize and avoid injuries.

3. To protect the environment.

4. To minimize property damage.



The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan is reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes.



The Appert's Foodservice facility is non-responding, and the facility plans to coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazard Analysis, performed on December 10-11, 2011, generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the Appert's Foodservice facility located in St. Cloud, Minnesota.  The mitigation measures include additional training, key maintenance related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  The Appert's Foodservice facility is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:



1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.



2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.



3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.



4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.





DATA ELEMENTS



The refrigeration system, System #1, has a maximum chemical inventory of 13,470 pounds.  EPA's CDX website requires the quantity of ammonia be rounded

to two significant digit for item 1.17.c; therefore, it is 13,000 pounds.  For item 3.5, EPA's CDX website requires the value to be whole number, which sould be 13,470 pounds.  However, EPA's CDX website would not allow the value in item 3.5 to be larger than the value in item 1.17.c.  Therefore, for item 3.5, it is reported as 13,000 pounds.
